title: How to Paint Ceramic Pots

steps.headline: Use a hose or your kitchen faucet to rinse your ceramic pot inside and out.
Scrub it with detergent and water using a scrub brush or abrasive pad.
steps.description: You can also use an old toothbrush to clean underneath the lip of the pot.

steps.headline: Rinse the pot well inside and out.
Set the pot in the sun and allow it to dry thoroughly.
Purchase glossy interior/exterior spray paint, 200-grit sandpaper, paintbrushes and a can of latex primer.
Put the pot outside on a table, preferably on a day that is not windy or rainy.
steps.description: Put a piece of cardboard, plastic sheeting or some newspapers on the table to protect it from the paint.

steps.headline: Sand the pot with sandpaper just enough to roughen up the glossy surface.
Wipe the pot down with a clean, damp cloth.
Apply the primer with a brush, and let it dry thoroughly.
steps.description: Latex primer adheres well to roughed-up ceramic. You can apply a second coat of primer to make sure you have perfect coverage. Let all coats dry completely.

steps.headline: Read the directions on the can before you begin painting.
steps.description: You usually need to shake the can vigorously first.

steps.headline: Spray the interior of the pot, using even, sweeping strokes.
Allow the inside paint to dry thoroughly.
steps.description: (If you don’t want to apply color to the inside, turn the pot upside down and proceed with the next step.)

steps.headline: Spray the exterior of the pot.
steps.description: Use sweeping motions so that the color goes on evenly.

steps.headline: Allow the pot to dry in the sun.
Save any leftover paint in case you need to do touch-ups.
Wait at least 24 hours after painting before you repot your plant.
Purchase unglazed ceramic pots at a craft store.
steps.description: These stores also carry a variety of paints, water sealers, finish glosses and brushes that are suitable for painting unglazed pots.

steps.headline: Choose a work area that is well-ventilated.
Cover your work surface with plastic or newspapers to protect it.
Remove seams on the pot that were created from the mold.
steps.description: Use a chisel to gently chip the seams off or sand them lightly with fine to medium grade sandpaper. This step is necessary for a smooth surface, and the paint will adhere better if you lightly sand it first.

steps.headline: Brush the pot off with a soft paint brush or a dry cloth.
steps.description: You can also blow off any dust and dirt with a hair dryer.

steps.headline: Wipe the pot down with a damp cloth.
Allow the pot to dry completely.
Spray the inside of your pot with a waterproof sealer.
steps.description: A sealer will help prevent moisture from soaking through the pot, which could ruin the outside finish.

steps.headline: Let the sealer dry completely.
Apply a primer to the ceramic pot using a paintbrush.
steps.description: The primer helps the final coat of paint adhere and it covers any small imperfections or discolorations.

steps.headline: Let the primer coat dry completely.
Brush a thin coat of acrylic paint on the entire pot.
steps.description: Use the best brush you can afford; the bristles on cheap brushes invariably come loose and get stuck in the paint.

steps.headline: Allow the paint to dry.
Apply another thin coat of paint to the ceramic pot and let it dry.
Use a thin coat of acrylic gloss to protect the paint.
Allow at least 24 hours of drying time before you put soil in the pot.
